paragraph: CHAPTER X.
tokens: x

paragraph: The next morning, when they assembled at breakfast, after Mr. Campbell had read the prayers, Mary Percival said, "Did you hear that strange and loud noise last night? I was very much startled with it; but, as nobody said a word, I held my tongue."
tokens: next morning assemble breakfast read prayer say hear strange loud noise last night startle say word hold tongue

paragraph: "Nobody said a word, because every body was fast asleep, I presume," said Alfred; "I heard nothing."
tokens: say word body fast asleep presume say hear

paragraph: "It was like the sound of cart-wheels at a distance, with whistling and hissing," continued Mary.
tokens: sound cart wheel distance whistling hissing continue

paragraph: "I think I can explain it to you, as I was up during the night, Miss Percival," said Captain Sinclair. "It is a noise you must expect every night during the summer season; but one to which you will soon be accustomed."
tokens: think explain night say noise expect night summer season accustom

paragraph: "Why, what was it?"
"Frogs,--nothing more; except, indeed, the hissing, which, I believe, is made by the lizards. They will serenade you every night. I only hope you will not be disturbed by any thing more dangerous."
tokens: frog more hissing believe make lizard serenade night hope disturb thing dangerous

paragraph: "Is it possible that such small creatures can make such a din?"
tokens: possible such small creature make din

paragraph: "Yes; when thousands join in the concert; I may say millions."
tokens: thousand join concert say million

paragraph: "Well, I thank you for the explanation, Captain Sinclair, as it has been some relief to my mind."
tokens: thank explanation relief mind

paragraph: After breakfast, Martin (we shall for the future leave out his surname) informed Mr. Campbell that he had seen Malachi Bone, the hunter, who had expressed great dissatisfaction at their arrival, and his determination to quit the place if they remained.
tokens: breakfast future leave surname inform see hunter express great dissatisfaction arrival determination quit place remain

paragraph: "Surely, he hardly expects us to quit the place to please him?"
tokens: expect quit place please

paragraph: "No," replied Martin; "but if he were cankered in disposition, which I will say Malachi is not, he might make it very unpleasant for you to remain, by bringing the Indians about you."
tokens: reply canker disposition say make unpleasant remain bring

paragraph: "Surely, he would not do that?" said Mrs. Campbell.
tokens: do say

paragraph: "No, I don't think he would," replied Martin; "because, you see, it's just as easy for him to go further off."
tokens: think reply see easy go

paragraph: "But why should we drive him away from his property any more than we leave our own?" observed Mrs. Campbell.
tokens: drive property more leave own observe

paragraph: "He says he won't be crowded, ma'am; he can't bear to be crowded."
tokens: say crowd bear crowd

paragraph: "Why, there's a river between us."
tokens: be river

paragraph: "So there is, ma'am, but still that's his feeling. I said to him, that if he would go, I dared say Mr. Campbell would buy his allotment of him, and he seems to be quite willing to part with it."
tokens: be feeling say go dare say buy allotment seem willing part

paragraph: "It would be a great addition to your property, Mr. Campbell," observed Captain Sinclair. "In the first place, you would have the whole of the prairie and the right of the river on both sides, apparently of no consequence now, but as the country fills up, most valuable."
tokens: great addition property observe first place have whole prairie right river side consequence country fill valuable

paragraph: "Well," replied Mr. Campbell, "as I presume we shall remain here, or, at all events, those who survive me will, till the country fills up, I shall be most happy to make any arrangement with Bone for the purchase of his property."
tokens: reply presume remain event survive country fill happy make arrangement purchase property

paragraph: "I'll have some more talk with him, sir,'" replied Martin.
tokens: have more talk sir reply

paragraph: The second day was passed as was the first, in making preparations for erecting the house, which, now that they had obtained such unexpected help, was, by the advice of Captain Sinclair, considerably enlarged beyond the size originally intended. As Mr. Campbell paid the soldiers employed a certain sum per day for their labor, he had less scruple in employing them longer. Two of them were good carpenters, and a sawpit had been dug, that they might prepare the doors and the frames for the window-sashes which Mr. Campbell had taken the precaution to bring with him. On the third day, a boat arrived from the fort bringing the men's rations and a present of two fine bucks from the commandant. Captain Sinclair went in the boat to procure some articles which he required, and returned in the evening. The weather continued fine, and in the course of a week, a great deal of timber was cut and squared. During this time, Martin had several meetings with the old hunter, and it was agreed that he should sell his property to Mr. Campbell. Money he appeared to care little about--indeed it was useless to him; gunpowder, lead, flints, blankets, and tobacco, were the principal articles requested in the barter; the amount, however, was not precisely settled. An intimacy had been struck up between the old hunter and John; in what manner it was difficult to imagine, as they both were very sparing of their words; but this was certain, that John had contrived to get across the stream somehow or another, and was now seldom at home to his meals. Martin reported that he was in the lodge of the old hunter, and that he could come to no harm; so Mrs. Campbell was satisfied.
tokens: second day pass first make preparation erect house obtain such unexpected help advice enlarge size intend pay soldier employ certain sum day labor have less scruple employ good carpenter sawpit dig prepare door frame window sashe take precaution bring third day boat arrive fort bring man ration present fine buck commandant go boat procure article require return evening weather continue fine course week great deal timber cut square time have several meeting old hunter agree sell property money appear care little useless gunpowder lead flint blanket tobacco principal article request barter amount settle intimacy strike old hunter manner difficult imagine sparing word certain contrive get stream home meal report lodge old hunter come harm satisfied

paragraph: "But what does he do there, Martin?" said Mrs. Campbell, as they were clearing away the table after supper.
tokens: do say clear table supper

paragraph: "Just nothing but look at the squaw, or at Malachi cleaning his gun, or any thing else he may see. He never speaks, that I know of, and that's why he suits old Malachi."

paragraph: "He brought home a whole basket of trout this afternoon," observed Mary; "so he is not quite idle."
tokens: bring whole basket trout afternoon observe idle

paragraph: "No, miss; he's fishing at daylight, and gives one-half to you and the other to old Bone. He'll make a crack hunter one of these days, as old Malachi says. He can draw the bead on the old man's rifle in good style already, I can tell you."

paragraph: "How do you mean, Martin?" said Mrs. Campbell.
tokens: mean say

paragraph: "I mean that he can fire pretty true, ma'am, although it's a heavy gun for him to lift; a smaller one would do better for him."

paragraph: "But is he not too young to be trusted with a gun, uncle?" said Mary.

paragraph: "No, miss," interrupted Martin, "you can't be too young here; the sooner a boy is useful the better; and the boy with a gun is almost as good as a man; for the gun kills equally as well if pointed true. Master Percival must have his gun as soon as I am at leisure to teach him."
tokens: miss interrupt young boy useful good boy gun good man gun kill point true have gun leisure teach

paragraph: "I wish you were at leisure now, Martin," cried Percival.
tokens: wish leisure cry

paragraph: "You forget, aunt, that you promised to learn to load and fire a rifle yourself," said Mary.

paragraph: "No. I do not; and I intend to keep my word, as soon as there is time; but John is so very young."

paragraph: "Well, Mary, I suppose we must enlist too?" said Emma.

paragraph: "Yes; we'll be the female rifle brigade," replied Mary, laughing.

paragraph: "I really quite like the idea," continued Emma; "I will put up with no impertinence, recollect, Alfred; excite my displeasure, and I shall take down my rifle."

paragraph: "I suspect you will do more execution with your eyes, Emma," replied Alfred, laughing.

paragraph: "Not upon a catamount, as Martin calls it. Pray what is a catamount?"

paragraph: "A painter, miss."

paragraph: "Oh, now I know; a catamount is a painter, a painter is a leopard or a panther.--As I live, uncle, here comes the old hunter, with John trotting at his heels. I thought he would come at last. The visit is to me, I'm sure, for when we first met he was dumb with astonishment."

paragraph: "You'll not hear my rifle," said the old hunter, after a pause; "but I'm thinking you'll never stay here. You don't know what an Ingen's life is; it ain't fit for the like of you. No, there's not one of you, 'cept this boy," continued Malachi, putting his hand on John's head, "that's fit for the woods. Let him come to me. I'll make a hunter of him; won't I, Martin?"

paragraph: "Why, what good can he do us?" inquired Henry.

paragraph: "A friend in need is a friend indeed, sir; and a friend in the wilderness is not to be thrown away. Old Malachi is going further out, and if danger occurs, we shall know it from him, for the sake of the boy, and have his help too, if we need it."

paragraph: "There is much good sense in Martin Super's remarks, Mr. Campbell," observed Captain Sinclair. "You will then have Malachi Bone as an advanced guard, and the fort to fall back upon, if necessary to retreat."
